fields.description:
Currently Stash does an MSSQL-specific JDBC URL check and refuses to start up if any other JDBC driver is used.

Please remove this hard-coded check so other MSSQL JDBC drivers like JNETDirect/JSQLConnect or Merant DataDirect or something else can be used.

This also clears the way for integrated authentication on Linux platforms as those other drivers support this authentication mode.
fields.summary: Remove the hard-coded MSSQL JDBC driver check

fields.description:
h3.Summary
Git clones and fetches over SSH are slower in Stash 3.11.0 and 3.11.1 than in previous releases.  In the SSH connection between the client and Stash, an approximately 2 second pause can be observed in which no data is transferred and nothing appears to be happening.  No additional CPU, memory, or I/O load is added during these pauses, but under heavy load of many small SSH requests (e.g., polling from CI servers), Stash may display "Stash is queuing requests" and "Stash is reaching resource limits" (as described in https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASHKB/Stash+is+reaching+resource+limits) more readily than in previous releases.  When Stash is queuing requests, all Git hosting operations, not just SSH clones and fetches, may take considerably (even minutes) longer, and may time out unnecessarily. 

h3.Workaround for Stash 3.11.0 and 3.11.1
# Download {{stash-scm-cache-1.5.6.jar}} attached to this issue.
# Log in to Stash as a system administrator, and go to *Administration > Add-Ons > Manage add-ons*.
# Click *Upload add-on*.
# Click the *Choose file* button and browse to {{stash-scm-cache-1.5.6.jar}}.
# Click the *Upload* button. 

h3. Solution
Upgrade to Stash 3.11.2.
fields.summary: Git clone and fetch over SSH slower in Stash 3.11.0

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Stash appears to be white-listing the URL schemes for URLs in commit messages. Some custom URL schemes (e.g rdar://) The rdar scheme is not included in the white-list. This means that the URLs are converted into a link, but the href attribute in the <a> tag is not present.

h3. Suggested Solution
 
Stash should support a configurable white-list for URL schemes, and Users should add rdar to that list.
fields.summary: Provide the ability to white-list custom URL schemes in commit message

fields.description:
I'm continuously updating a tag, which is being pulled checked out by another repository.
After the update, the checkout of the tag does not check out the commit it is *actually* referencing, but a stale commit instead (the one before the update).

Steps to reproduce:

In repo1:
* git add .
* git commit -m "Commit one"
* git tag -a 0.0.1
* git push origin master --tags

In repo2:
* git clone repo1 
* git checkout 0.0.1

In repo1: 
* (make changes)
* git add .
* git commit --amend
* git tag -f -a 0.0.1
* git push origin master -f --tags

In repo2: 
* git fetch && git checkout 0.0.1

Expected: 
I receive the updated commit I just pushed to repo1

Actual: 
I receive the stale commit that was tagged before I updated 0.0.1
fields.summary: Checking out tag after updating returns stale content

fields.description:
h3.  Request
According to the documentation at https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Using+repository+permissions, there are six kinds of actions on which you can allow/disallow permissions:
# Browse
# Clone, fork, pull
# Create, browse, or comment on a pull request
# Merge a pull request
# Push
# Edit settings and permissions

Currently, the least-permissive access you can grant to a user (of "admin", "write", and "read") is "read" (1+2+3).  We are requesting a fourth level of access that is more restrictive, perhaps called "browse-only" or "web-only", which would be limited to (1+3).

h3. Motivation for this request:

Our company has several repos in Stash with high-security IP, and we generally follow the principle of least privilege -- unless a person has a legitimate reason to clone a repo on your local machine (or fork it into your private space), we don't want to grant read access.

This is a pain point for our product managers.  They use JIRA extensively, our JIRA instance is linked to Stash, and they can see in a JIRA issue that there has been related Stash activity.  We want them to be able to use Stash to see the source (most importantly, to participate in the discussions surrounding a pull request), but we don't want to grant them all the permissions that come with "read" access.

Our concern is that if we granted read access, some would use that privilege to clone the repos locally.  We don't want our product managers to be walking around with copies of the source code on their machines -- the majority of them use laptops, and we don't want to put our IP at risk if their laptop is stolen or compromised.  If we could grant "browse-only" access, we could put up a reasonable deterrent to this behavior and encourage them to only view the repo through Stash's web UI.
fields.summary: Please provide a "browse-only" permissions setting, more restrictive than "read"

fields.description:
I've configured Stash to sit behind a NetScaler Load Balancer and trying to perform SSL traffic between the client and the LB and then in the clear to the stash server.
I can log on successfully via http://localhost:7990.
When accessing via the load balancer over https://stash.domainname.com I can't authenticate.
I've included the configuration and some log files as well as fiddler traces for both cases.
I've used https://stash.domainname.com as the server address, so should expect all the content to render properly and don't have the SCCM configuration enabled to allow clients to perform HTTPS gets. 
The LB is configured to perform regular HTTP redirection to the actual server on port 7990.
Please see attached logs for more details.
fields.summary: Issue configuring through Load Balancer (NetScaler) and HTTPs

fields.description:
Hi,
I'm looking to secure access to the internet via an authenticated proxy and would like to avoid username passwords within init strings.

https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRAKB/How+to+Configure+an+Outbound+HTTP+and+HTTPS+Proxy+for+JIRA
describes a scenario where this may be possible, -Dhttp.auth.ntlm.domain=DOMAIN used in conjunction with -Dhttp.proxyAuth=ntlm,basic

Is this supported if I use the following on the Java service properties?

-Dhttp.proxyHost=proxy.example.org -Dhttp.proxyPort=8080 -Dhttps.proxyHost=proxy.example.org -Dhttps.proxyPort=8080 -Dhttp.nonProxyHosts=localhost


Thanks
Andrew 

*Workaround:*

While the problem statement above is a known issue and Atlassian decided not to implement NTLM support for a few products, there is a workaround for that available on the documentation below:
- [How to configure an outbound HTTP and HTTPS proxy for Stash|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASHKB/How+to+configure+an+outbound+HTTP+and+HTTPS+proxy+for+Stash]
fields.summary: Use integrated Windows Auth for Proxy Authentication

fields.description:
When I receive mail about other people's comments on the pull request, always include my current status on the pull request.

For example: I go into a pull request, make a few comments and approve it.  A day later, other people comment on it... and I have to recall... did I comment on this yet?  Did I review it?  Did I approve it?  I have to open the pull request to check that whereas if my current activity on the pull request was in the footer of the notification, I'd know that I already dealt with that pull request.

When there are a pile of open pull requests, it starts getting hard to remember which are outstanding in my inbox and which aren't.
fields.summary: Include my current activity on pull request email notifications

*Administration menu*

* Application Links
* Clustering

*Repository Administration*

* Pull requests

The following translations can be improved:

*Under Clustering*

* the string "Loption" should be "L'option"
* the string "Performance déchelle" should be "Performance d'échelle" (though, this translation should be reviewed, not really french).
* "sans temps darrêt" => "sans temps d'arrêt"
* "même en cas de pics de charge" => "même en cas de pique de charge
* "Loption de déploiement du Centre de Données est conçue pour bénéficier dune haute disponibilité et dune haute performance déchelle" => "L'option de déploiement du Centre de Données est conçue pour bénéficier d'une haute disponibilité et d'une haute performance d'échelle"

*During a Git push*

* "remote: Vérifiez la configuration de vos autorisations de branches avec ladministrateur de projet" should be "remote: Vérifiez la configuration de vos autorisations de branches avec l'administrateur du projet".

*Configuring repository permissions*

* "Lecteur" (reader) should be "Lecture" when you want to mention something is for "reading" (read-only).

*When pushing a new branch and pull request should be created*

{code}"remote: Créer une demander pour bugfix/..."{code}

Should be either:

{code}"remote: Créer une demande d'intégration pour bugfix/..."
OR
"remote: Créer une demande pour bugfix/..."{code}

*When pushing to a read-only repository*

{code}fatal: remote error: Autorisations insuffisantes
Vous ne pouvez pusher sur ABC/defg. Pusher nécessite un droit décriture et
vous navez quun droit de lecture.{code}

Should be:

{code}fatal: remote error: Autorisations insuffisantes
Vous ne pouvez pousser (push) sur ABC/defg. Pousser (push) nécessite un droit d'écriture mais vous n'avez qu'un droit de lecture.{code}

fields.description:
It seems to not be possible to add _another_ user as a watcher via the API.
I can understand why the web UI doesn't allow this: it is a somewhat rare use case (but do note that Jira itself DOES allow this feature, and it is sometimes quite handy).

But for the Rest API, which is by definition used to automate tasks and build tooling, I think it does make a lot of sense to be able to manipulate the watcher list.

My use case is a internal tool that help us with code reviews where you can add rules , e.g. "automatically add Bob as a watcher to any Pull Request that contains Security related code".

So, the same way the REST API allows to add/remove arbitrary reviewers, it would be good to have that capability for pull requests watchers as well.
fields.summary: Rest API: Allow to add *another* user as a watcher on a PR

fields.description:
When I started, this was the state:

* No "development" branch selected
* No "production" branch selected
* Bugfix, Feature, Hotfix prefixes chosen

At first, I tried to only set the Development and Production branches, and then check the "enable automatic merging" checkbox. When I clicked Save, the two branches were saved, but the checkbox for automatic merging was unset.

I then tried just checking the checkbox again, and clicking Save, and it still didn't work.

Then I tried enabling the Release branch prefix, checking the checkbox, then clicking Save. That seemed to work.

fields.description: I created a pull request that contains a file that I changed (e.g. Foo.java). At some point after I created the pull request, Foo.java was deleted from master. Afterwards, Foo.java doesn't appears in the pull request, it's not in the list of files in the file hierarchy under the Diff tab.
fields.summary: File disappears from pull request if that file was removed in master

fields.description:
Stash keeps track of steps in a pull request and shows when commits are added or removed.
I would like to add comments to those events.
For example, we enforce a final rebase once the PR has been reviewed, thus a last update to the pull request is to be made. Commit logs and diff have not changed, and I would like, as a developer, to inform the reviewer that the update is only a rebase.
fields.summary: Add comments to pull request updates

fields.description:
We're in a situation where we have customized our git workflow, to the point that the merge conflict suggestions during pull requests do not match the reality of what a developer should do in the event of a merge conflict. We block pushes to our integration branches, we require that 1 extra user approves a pull request, and we require 1 good build from our Build Agents.
This has us in a situation where we cannot follow the instructions in the merge conflict message that stash delivers, which ends up confusing new engineers, and causing issues for those that don't develop on shared projects all the time.

We would like to customize the message to something that suits our workflow better.
fields.summary: Custom merge conflict message

fields.description: The feature "Unapprove all reviewers when the source branch of a pull request changes" is really good, however the is no way for the developer to know if it's the system that has unapproved it, or the reviewer has unapproved it.   To the developer, it just looks like the reviewer has changed his mind...
fields.summary: Stash auto unapprove should identify it's a system unapproval, not a user unapproval

fields.description:
There is a new setting in Stash "Unapprove all reviewers when the source branch of a pull request changes"

This is awesome feature for is, sadly it's not practical to use, as merges (typically developers keeping their branches updated - something we encourage) means pull requests are often unapproved, sometimes many many times.

It would be really nice if we could exclude merges from this auto unapprove feature.
fields.summary: Merges should not invalidate pull request approvals

fields.description:
Hello,

A pull request can contain "linked" JIRA IDs. Under "linked" I meant creation of an attribute of a pull request so it is returned by REST API (/jira/1.0/pull-request/###/issues) and displayed at right panel of pull request UI.

Currently JIRA ID is linked with a pull request if it is specified:
 * in any of commits messages for this pull request
 * in the Title of a pull request
 * in the "source" branch name of the pull request

If a JIRA ID is placed in Details section or in the comments of a pull request it is just "converted" to a HTML link to JIRA but it is _not_ an attribute of a pull request (and _not_ returned by REST API call). I can agree that Comments (for code changes or pull request itself) may not be the right place to "link" JIRA IDs from - they can be just mentioned during discussion. But the Details section - is definitely the right place.

Could you please:
 * Add possibility to "link" with a pull request JIRA IDs specified in Details section of a pull request
or
 * Add markup construction to "link" JIRA IDs from any section of a pull request

Thank You,
Sergey
fields.summary: Link a pull request with JIRA IDs specified in Details and/or Comments

{panel:title=What needs to be improved?|borderColor=#ccc| titleBGColor=#faacad|bgColor=#fff}
I see a problem (or I think I do).

I want to get all the commits between a tag and the HEAD of a branch. 
To do so I'm using the following call:
http://apps-stash.asml.com:7990/rest/api/1.0/projects/YS/repos/YIELDSTAR/commits?limit=100000&since=start_ys300c_sp__05&until=release/ys300c_sp_05

Where 'start_ys300c_sp__05' is a label and 'release/ys300c_sp_05' is 
a branch. Currently the label and the HEAD of the branch are pointing 
to the same commit (67415ee569d4496dd997fc51ea69ffff924a27f1). When I 
do the REST API call as mentioned above I'll get over 5000 entries 
back, while I expect none.

When I call:
http://apps-stash.asml.com:7990/rest/api/1.0/projects/YS/repos/YIELDSTAR/commits?limit=100000&since=67415ee569d4496dd997fc51ea69ffff924a27f1&until=release/ys300c_sp_05 
I do get none commits back. So my conclusion is that the 'since' clause 
does only work with SHA1 hashes and not with tags (nor with branch names).

I'm using Atlassian Stash v3.10.0.

Regards,
Rudy Holtkamp 
{panel}

*Reporter*: Rudy Holtkamp
*E-mail*: [mailto:Rudy.Holtkamp@tmc.nl]
fields.summary: Unexpected results using REST API (since, until)

fields.description:
To be consitent with JIRA and Confluence, Stash should allow for the date and time formats (used e.g. on the commits page) to be _customizable_.

A simple key=value attribute in the stash {{config.properties}} would be sufficient.

Component: Internationalization
fields.summary: Date & time format options, or localisation

fields.description: Unified diff is impossible to read if there are lots of changes or if stash can't work out what the change was, side by side diff is more effective most of the time.
fields.summary: Make side-by-side diff the default

fields.description:
msysgit has added support for long (>260 char) file paths in Windows, provided all clients and servers explicitly enable the {{core.longpaths}} option.  They document: "Only enable this if you know what you're doing and are prepared to live with a few quirks."  See https://github.com/msysgit/git/commit/c5f98452e98dca292c615000df7973ead63cf29b.

Stash doesn't support long file paths in Git repositories on Windows and has known issues if they are used, see https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASHKB/Stash+always+shows+incorrect+Merge+Conflict+in+PRs for example. 

This suggestion is to improve Stash so that long file paths can be fully supported on Windows, provided the {{core.longpaths}} git option is enabled on the server and all clients.
fields.summary: Add support for long (>260 char) file paths in Windows

fields.description:
My team uses a git-flow branch approach but ensures that branches are properly rebased before being merged (using --no-ff). This way, commit history is clean and features are grouped and represented graphically as "humps". No two "humps" must be interleaved.

Looking at STASH-2874, there seems to be no easy way of auto rebasing before merging, so "rebase please" is a common task before the pull request can be merged.

As a reviewer (and pull request merger) I found no easy way of knowing where the branch of a pull request starts (ie. last common commit between target) and therefore if I need to ask the developper to rebase its branch.

If {{develop}} is the target branch for a pull request, I would like to see a message in the pull request page that says "Starts @ {{develop}}" or "Starts 2 commits behind {{develop}}" or something like this.

May be of help : {{git merge-base --fork-point}} (with git >= 1.9)

Thanks
fields.summary: Display fork point of a pull request

fields.description:
How to reproduce:

* fork a repository
* create a new branch {{foo}}
* Go to the branches page
* select {{foo}} as the base branch ({{foo}} does not exist in the original repo)
* create a pull request for any branch using the actions menu
* result page is 404 : unknown refs/target/foo

It seems that creating a pull request uses the current active branch in someway. This is tricky because I would expect the pull request page to show up and propose the usual source_repo/source_branch → target_repo/target_branch dialog.

_EDIT_: this only occurs when the active branch does not exist in the target repository
fields.summary: Creating a pull request for the current active branch results in 404

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
1. Create new pull request
2. Type some text in description
3. Move cursor into middle of text
4. Paste image

Expected behavior: markup is inserted onto cursor position, just like in JIRA

Actual: markup is inserted at the end of textarea

Additional problems:
- can't ctrl+z
- cursor is moved to the end of textarea
- -apparently file is not uploaded asynchronously-

Please refer to image paste feature in JIRA.
fields.summary: Image paste at cursor position not at the end of textarea

when *latest* is used it give a 404

fields.summary: branch-permissions REST API not accepting latest API level

fields.description:
Pull requests that were approved, not yet merged, then updated by the developer are not getting automatically unapproved. Merging them merges unapproved changes.

This results in unapproved code getting into the repository, which is a huge compliance and security hole.

*Example:*
Developer changes file f1 on feature/123, commits it, then pushes and creates pull request
Senior developer reviews and approves pull request (but it's not yet merged)
Developer changes file f2 on feature/123, commits it, then pushes again
Senior developer merges the pull request
*At this point unreviewed and unapproved f2 gets into the system!*

There's an unofficial plugin to address this, and it's unsupported by Atlassian. Pull requests are integral part of Atlassian Stash, and this is a bug that introduces a huge security and compliance issue.
fields.summary: Updated pull requests don't automatically get unapproved

fields.description:
*Description:*

Git Tags created using https://developer.atlassian.com/static/rest/stash/3.10.0/stash-scm-git-rest.html#idp14096 and pushed to specific commits do not show in the Commits page in the UI until after a change is made to a tag using either cli or Sourcetree.

Example:
!tags-1.jpg|thumbnail!
!tags-2.jpg|thumbnail!

*Workaround:*

However, if you create another tag and push it  from the client all the previously created tags will become visible immediately. Refer to BSERV-8294 for more details.
fields.summary: Annotated tags pushed to specific commits from REST API do not show in the UI Commits Page

fields.description:
Hello!

There should be an option for clearing the list of Recently Viewed repositories in Stash and starting over at nothing. Otherwise repositories that have been deprecated in the environment or repositories that a user only needed to reference once can be removed, while repositories that are frequently developed against by the user will simply return to the list.

fields.description:
When using Stash and JIRA in French (and other alternative languages) you can't transition JIRA tickets from within Stash and are greeted with the following error message;

!Screen Shot 2015-07-21 at 09.56.39.png|thumbnail!

It appears that because the workflow transitions are not translated in JIRA, Stash can't match up the transition names during the REST call.

For example if you try to close the JIRA ticket in Stash with the resolution as *Doublon*, because in JIRA this is still registered as *Duplicate* you receive the error;

bq. Le nom de résolution 'Doublon' n'est pas valide

The REST call used to transition the issue should use the none translated transition value - for the default workflow at least.

*Steps to Reproduce*

1. Jira and stash linked via applinks.
2. Set your profile language to french 
3. Select a jira issue which has a Pull request in the stash repo. 
4. Click on it, and navigate to Stash.
5. In stash select the ticket, and in the following window try to resolve the issue. Select any resolution.

*Workaround*

To work around this you can modify the resolution values in JIRA so that they match the French equivalents in Stash.
fields.summary: Can't transition JIRA issues from within Stash in alternate language

fields.description:
A user containing Unicode characters (e.g., "ñ") in the slug causes trouble both for browsing and cloning. For example, currently you are allowed to create a user with slug *daureña* but then some operations involving this user work, and some don't:
h3. Web access

*Works*
 - Accessing the user profile from browser history
 - [http://localhost:7990/users/dauren%CC%83a]
 - [http://localhost:7990/admin/users/view?name=daure%C3%B1a]

*Doesn't work*
 - typing 'ñ'
 - [http://localhost:7990/users/daure%C3%B1a]
 - [http://localhost:7990/admin/users/view?name=dauren%CC%83a]
h5. Command-line

*Works*
 - git clone [http://dauren%CC%83a@localhost:7990/scm/~dauren%CC%83a/daurena.git]
 - git clone [http://daure%C3%B1a@localhost:7990/scm/~dauren%CC%83a/daurena.git]

*Doesn't Work*
 - git clone [http://daure%C3%B1a@localhost:7990/scm/~daure%C3%B1a/daurena.git]
 - git clone [http://dauren%CC%83a@localhost:7990/scm/~daure%C3%B1a/daurena.git] (Auth fails)
 - git clone [http://daure|http://daure/]ña@localhost:7990/scm/~daure%C3%B1a/daurena.git
 - git clone [http://daure|http://daure/]ña@localhost:7990/scm/~daureña/daurena.git
h3. Other symptoms of the problem

Renaming a user will return "The user could not be renamed":
 !BSERV7645_renameuser.png|width=400!

Saving changes in the user details will return "The server didn't respond. You may retry your request when the server comes back up":
 !BSERV7645_savechanges.png|width=400!

Changing the password will return "The password could not be changed":
 !BSERV7645_savepassword.png|width=400!

When accessing the Global Permissions, the list of users and group will not load:
 !BSERV7645_globalpermissions.png|width=400!
h3. Workaround

Rename the user so that the slug contains only ASCII characters.

+Alternative workaround+

If the user cannot be renamed via the user interface:

# Logout from Bitbucket Server

# use the following query to update the SYS.ADMIN user
 (!) Always back up your data before performing any modifications to the database. If possible, test any insert, update, or delete SQL commands on a staging server first.
{noformat}
UPDATE sta_normal_user
SET name = '<your_name>', slug = '<your_slug>'
WHERE user_id = '<user_id>'

{noformat}
fields.summary: Allow Unicode characters in user slug

fields.description: As part of adding pluggable SSH authentication, the knowledge of which SshKey matched the presented public key was lost from DefaultPublicKeyAuthenticator and so could not be encoded in the access logs as a label nor included in the authentication event. This is an unfortunate regression as there's now no way to know which key was used for SSH authentication for an SCM request.
fields.summary: Access log regression for SSH authentication
Make "path" optional for the pull requests comments REST API function

fields.description:
It would be useful to be able to change the favicon in Stash to reflect other aesthetic changes that are made, as can be done to a certain extent with the [Stash Look and Feel Plugin|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.atlassian.stash.plugin.stash-look-and-feel-plugin], although this still doesn't allow for favicon editing.

*Workaround*
It is possible to do this manually by swapping out the favicon.ico file in the installation directory ({{<stash_installation_directory/atlassian-stash/static/images}}) that is used for a custom one.

This will probably be cached by the browser so the cache will need to be cleared in order for the new favicon show up.
fields.summary: Ability to change the favicon for Stash

fields.description:
JIRA has the capability to send an e-mail notification to all users from the administration UI: JRA-2287.

It would be helpful if Stash administrators could also easily users about a downtime beforehand, but it can be handy for other types of communication.
fields.summary: Ability for administrators to send notification to all Stash users

Thank you for your consideration of this request.

{noformat}


*Reproducing the Problem:*

1) Create a repository with a clone of the Linux kernel

2) Restart Stash (The problem occurs when building the SCM upload-pack cache file. If the below clones all experience a cache hit this problem does not occur).

3) Execute, locally on the same server as Stash, 20 concurrent git clones of the repository. These should be executed at the same instant so a script like this works best:

{code}
#!/bin/bash
for i in $(seq 1 20)
do
    git clone http://localhost:7990/scm/project/linux-clone.git linux$i > log$i 2>&1 &
done
{code}

Repeat steps 2 & 3 some number of times to reproduce the problem. In my test environment I am able to reproduce it approximately 1 in 5 executions of the test.

This problem was reproduced in the same environment described in STASH-7518 and it is necessary to have the fix for STASH-7518 applied otherwise it is much more likely you will run into that problem instead.

It should be noted that the symptoms of this bug and STASH-7518 are quite different:
- STASH-7518 - Some Git clones *hang* and the Stash access logs show the operation is completing in *~200ms*
- This bug - Some Git clones *abort* with an "early EOF" error and the Stash access logs show the operations is completing in *many tens of seconds* (typically 40-90s depending on the performance of the platform).

*Root Cause:*
In the above test, 1 clone (actually the server side thread handling the clone) will become responsible for building the upload-pack and creating the cache file. The other 19 clones will be serviced from threads reading from this cache file.

The 19 reader threads are able to read the cache file while the writer thread is still writing it. These 19 readers will block until the first byte is read and then start reading. A race occurs between the writer and readers, and the problem described here occurs when the reader threads read to the end of the file before it is completed writing. In this case read() returns -1; this is interpreted as EOF, the data is written to the output stream and the connection closed.

I have observed that typically the writer thread grows the file faster than the readers can consume it. However this is not always true as the first few hundred bytes of the file are written. As a result, we can observe that this failure coincides roughly with the first byte being written to the cache file.

{{AbstractCacheEntry$SyncingInputStream.shouldWaitForData()}} attempts to prevent this problem from happening, and this check, {{bytesRead == bytesWritten}}, is aimed at ensuring we don't read when there is no data to be read. However {{bytesWritten}} merely indicates how many bytes have been written to the {{OutputStream}}. But in practice that isn't translating into a guarantee that the data is available in the file to the reader.
fields.summary: Race condition in content-cache's AbstractCacheEntry

fields.description:
Hello Stash team,

I suggest we add a few columns to the existing Repositories listing page in order to make it much more useful. Now the listing page has nothing but the names (with link) of the repositories, can we have extra columns such as "last modified date time", "last commit hash", "last committer name", "branches count" on it? It would be better if we can sort the list by clicking on those columns.

Thanks.
fields.summary: Show "signs of life" on repositories listing page

fields.description:
Stash used to show absolute dates. An intended bugfix for poorly formatted dates has since caused us to show relative dates, which become incorrect a minute later.

!relative-email-time.png!
fields.summary: Emails show relative time

fields.description:
Rationale:
* github has it,
* gitlab has it,
* reviewboard has it,
* ... name an other solution ... has it,
* It hurts developers' productivity when they have to click click click around all the time.

This is not a new request:
* https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/STASH-2855
* https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/STASH-7005
* https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/STASH-7039

Would it please be possible to enable this feature, maybe controlled by a user preference if you are worried this hurts performance; or where items are loading as the user scrolls to the bottom (infinite -scrollbar style).

This routinely comes up as a blocker for adoption, and leads us to consider alternatives.
fields.summary: View all diffs in a single page.

fields.description:
It would be beneficial to be able to refuses pushes to a branch when they come from a branch on which there are unmet conditions in a pull request.

Use case:

* User creates pull request on feature branch.
* Some conditions (e.g. approval) are not satisfied.
* User merges to integration branch locally.
* User pushes.

Actual result: push succeeds and pull request is complete.
Desired result: push fails with message to user that conditions are not met and pull request remains incomplete. (User must rebase and go through the correct procedure.)
fields.summary: Prevent pushes while a Pull request has unsatisfied conditions

fields.description:
h3. Summary
The bundled winp library will kill random processes, one of which can be Stash itself. 

h3. Environment

* If in a Windows VM the blue screen of death is most common.
* If not on a VM, Stash will most likely crash randomly with no errors. 

h3. Results

The following can be found in the memory dump:
{code}nt!KeBugCheckEx
nt!PspCatchCriticalBreak+0xad
nt! ?? ::NNGAKEGL::`string'+0x48196
nt!PspTerminateProcess+0x6d
nt!NtTerminateProcess+0x9e
nt!KiSystemServiceCopyEnd+0x13
ntdll!NtTerminateProcess+0xa
KERNELBASE!TerminateProcess+0x25
winp_x64_35A3F35D2ED629A6CEC5B41DD1D280C3!Java_org_jvnet_winp_Native_noop+0x178
0x2638
0x1{code}
If you think you are running into this bug, please open a support ticket and send us a support zip  with a memory dump. Navigate to {{C:\Windows\}} and check if {{memory.dmp}} file is available. Please attach it to the case.

h3.Workaround
There is not a great workaround other than to upgrade to one of the fixed versions (4.0.0, 3.11.1, 3.10.4).
fields.summary: Stash on Windows causing BSOD or Stash will crash silently

fields.description: Is there a way that i can disable forking by default on stash
fields.summary: Stash-Disable Forking by Default

fields.description:
Currently anyone can close tasks.   I would like Stash to have the option that only the "owner" of the pull request can complete them.  The "originator" of the PR task should be able to delete them if they are no longer required.

Another desire, per BSERV-8578 would be a permission to only allow the creator of the task to mark it as completed (ie a reviewer in a subsequent review).
fields.summary: Pull Request Task Permissions.

fields.description:
Default Merge Conflict Instruction offers to resolve conflicts in target branch of Pull Request, and then merge it directly in the branch. Commonly, the target branch is master and direct push is not allowed (by hooks), so default instruction becomes wrong for  our users. 
It is very desirable to have ability to turn off the current instruction by any way. 
We could not find out how to do it through plugin development (may be you could help?), 
so we ask the feature.
fields.summary: Merge Conflicts Instruction is not applicable when branch permissions are in effect

fields.description:
h3. Problem statement

After fixing STASH-6868 which describes:
{quote}
The default value of {{executor.max.threads}} is 100 which is fine for average sized instances, but probably too small for very large instances.  This limit is often the first one to be hit on instances with very high (especially SSH clone) hosting workload.  The value should be increased, preferably scaling with instance size. 
{quote}

We introduced a formula for {{executor.max.threads=20*cpu+100}} as can be seen on [Stash config properties - Executor|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Stash+config+properties#Stashconfigproperties-Executor].

The problem is that this value could be too big for big instances, generating errors like:
{noformat}
Exception in thread "ssh:thread-5" java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: unable to create new native thread
	at java.lang.Thread.start0(Native Method)
	at java.lang.Thread.start(Thread.java:714)
	at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.addWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:950)
	at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.processWorkerExit(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1018)
	at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1160)
	at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:617)
	at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:745)
{noformat}

Or

{noformat}
2015-03-24 18:46:39,850 ERROR [AtlassianEvent::thread-23]  c.a.e.i.AsynchronousAbleEventDispatcher There was an exception thrown trying to dispatch event [com.atlassian.crowd.event.user.UserAttributeStoredEvent@d1e8fd3f] from the invoker [SingleParameterMethodListenerInvoker{method=public void com.atlassian.stash.internal.license.DefaultLicensedUserCountCache.onUserUpdatedEvent(com.atlassian.crowd.event.user.UserUpdatedEvent), listener=com.atlassian.stash.internal.license.DefaultLicensedUserCountCache@1301e2fa}]
java.lang.RuntimeException: unable to create new native thread
	at com.atlassian.event.internal.SingleParameterMethodListenerInvoker.invoke(SingleParameterMethodListenerInvoker.java:54) [atlassian-event-2.3.5.jar:na]
	at com.atlassian.event.internal.AsynchronousAbleEventDispatcher$1$1.run(AsynchronousAbleEventDispatcher.java:48) [atlassian-event-2.3.5.jar:na]
	at com.google.common.util.concurrent.MoreExecutors$SameThreadExecutorService.execute(MoreExecutors.java:253) [guava-11.0.2-atlassian-02.jar:na]
	at com.atlassian.event.internal.AsynchronousAbleEventDispatcher.dispatch(AsynchronousAbleEventDispatcher.java:107) [atlassian-event-2.3.5.jar:na]
{noformat}

We should check the number of CPUs available and have a ceiling for that value to avoid such scenarios.

h3. Workaround

Set in your {{stash-config.properties}} a fixed value for {{executor.max.threads}} which is lower and is reasonable to your system. This will overwrite the formula we ship by default once you restart Stash.
fields.summary: executor.max.threads is too big for instances with too many CPUs

fields.description: I would like to be able to apply a single Hipchat configuration per project, rather than only per repository. I think repository specific configurations should override the project settings, but in most cases so far since STASH-4260 was added, I have used an identical Hipchat configuration for each repository in my project(s).
fields.summary: Project level Hipchat configuration

fields.description:
For reference I am referring to the behavior that Bamboo has when creating a Hipchat notification:
"Check this box to notify room participants (ie via Growl) of the new message."

This would be *very* useful for our workflow. Right now email notifications are either not checked, or lost amidst the mass of emails, or due to STASH-4260 (thanks!) there is a message in Hipchat about PR details, but no one notices it as there is no notification.
fields.summary: Make Hipchat pull request notifications able to "notify" users in the Hipchat room when the Hipchat notification is sent

fields.description: I like to have a clean commit history. When I address pull request comments, I won't do so by using an additional commit but instead amend an existing commit. This keeps the history from having hundreds of "addressing PR comments" commits. However, when doing this reviewers don't easily know what I have changed Stash will say I "updated the pull request by adding 1 commit and removing 1 commit." Reviewers then have to either try to parse what has changed between these two commits or review the entire file again. It would be great if Stash would show a diff between these two commits.
fields.summary: Show diffs on pull requests when removing & adding commits

fields.description:
It's typical for us to review a pull request per commit. We try to create a clean commit history, so it's basically easier to view one commit after another. The main problem with pull requests here is, if you comment a line in a commit, this comment will not show up in the pull request activity.

This behavior forces us to have two views open. One showing the reviewed commit, and one the pull request 'Diff' view, where we have to add the comment.

Please make Stash remember, that a commit was opened from a pull request, and make the comments entered there appear in the pull request activity list.
fields.summary: Make comments for commits opened from pull requests appear in the pull request activity list

fields.description:

# In a diff view, add a line comment
# Type text really fast™

Expected: Text appears instantly
Actual: It appears with some lag (the more you type the longer it lags behind). If no lag is noticeably, check out the CPU usage.
fields.summary: Typing in comment of diff view is slow and causes heavy CPU use

fields.description:
According to the documentation creating feature branches should not be possible when a branch permission is applied for feature branches, using the new Branch Model option.

However when applying a branch permission using the Barnch Model option specific for feature branches a user that is not part of the user or group list specified in the permission can still create feature branches. The same user cannot push to or delete the branch.

If a permission is applied for the same users and groups using a Branch Pattern : 'feature/*' the user is (besides pushing and deleting) not able to create a feature branch.
fields.summary: Creating branches is still possible despite branch permission on branch model

fields.description:
When a user has been assigned branch permissions (see screenshot) the backwards compatible branchPermissionService.findPermittedEntities does not return this user. No users are returned.

This breaks functionality for plugins that  use branchPermissionService instead of DefaultRestrictionService (3.10 only) for backwards compatibility.
fields.summary: Stash 3.10 branchPermissionService.findPermittedEntities broken

fields.description: The Stash UI incorrectly identifies the "Author Date" of a commit as "Commit Date".
fields.summary: Stash display "Author Date" as "Commit Date" in Commits view

fields.description: In our environment, it would be helpful if stash could send an email to the team members when there is an auto merge failure caused by a conflict.  This would allow team members to hold off their merges so they wouldn't pile on to the original conflicting commit.
fields.summary: Add notification for auto merge failure.

fields.description:
h4. Problem
The currently widely used IPv4 address pool is close to exhaustion: [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IPv4_address_exhaustion]. IPv6 is around already for a while, however parts of our products may (and do) break.

h4. Requirement
- Add IPv6 tests for products and clarify it being supported for all parts of the products (external system connectivity, applinks, self-naming, reverse-proxying, etc).
- Update the supported platforms documentation and explicitly specify IPv6 to be supported to avoid confusion and give support a reference point.
fields.summary: Support for IPv6

fields.description:
I know that unified diff has problems showing syntax highlighting (STASH-2823), but choosing side-by-side diff is disabled for added files (and deleted, but those aren't as interesting) during Pull Requests, so no syntax highlighting is applied, making it more difficult than it has to be to review.

Workflow now is to open the whole file to get highlighting, then if I have anything to comment on, go back to the PR. Seems unnecessary.

On another, related note: I don't need the green/red color all over the place in the diff for added/removed.

This is using Stash server v3.7.0 btw.
fields.summary: Syntax highlighting in deleted and added files

fields.description:
I just tested this and it was working fine in version 3.9.2.

The following 2 scenarios can reproduce this after out-of-the-box install of either Stash 3.10.0 or 3.10.2:
(See comments - Alex Lopez confirmed that the issue is also present in 3.10.3)

*Scenario 1:*
Add 2 branch permissions:
Pattern * to limit write access to user1
Pattern feature/* to limit write access to user2

After adding these 2 permissions, the expected behavior is for user2 to have write access to feature/123, but instead the following error is shown

*{color:#d04437}remote: Branch refs/heads/feature/123 is read-only.
remote: Check your branch permissions configuration with the project administrator.
{color}*

*Scenario 2:*
Add 2 branch permissions:
Pattern branch* to limit write access to user1
Pattern branch1* to limit write access to user2

Expected behavior is for user2 to be able to write to branch123, but instead we get the "read-only" error here too.
fields.summary: Branch Permissions should not prevent push if multiple Restrictions match the target branch, and at least one allows write access to the current user or group

fields.description:
When deleting a branch via the branch list, the "base ref" is not updated correctly when switching it via the picker at the top of the page. 
This is visible in the "delete branch confirmation dialog", which will show the old base ref in the confirmation message. 
See attached screenshot for details.
fields.summary: Base Ref does not update for "delete branch confirmation" when switching in branch list

fields.description:
In Confluence, I can Watch documents or Spaces and get updates when something is changed. It would be nice to have the same ability with files or repos in Stash. A similar feature as the Star or Watch functionality in GitHub is what I want I guess. Or is this already possible and I'm missing it?
Thanks!
fields.summary: Ability to Watch files or repos in Stash
